title: Pentagon Orders 7,000 More Troops to Europe

Austin III ordered an additional 7,000 troops to Europe with the continent facing the biggest land war since World War II.

title: ‘The Crown’ Jewels, and Other Props, Reported Stolen Amid Filming
description: More than 200 props valued at roughly $200,000, including antiques, a replica of a Fabergé egg, silver and gold candelabra and part of a grandfather clock, were reportedly stolen.
content: It was not quite a royal heist.

title: Putin’s Case for War, Annotated
description: For the second time in days, President Vladimir V. Putin addressed Russians about his aims in Ukraine. A close look at his speech offers hints to what may lie ahead.
content: When Vladimir V. Putin announced Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in a televised address on Thursday, he articulated aims far beyond those of Russia’s prior assaults on its Ukrainian neighbor.

title: Stocks and Energy Markets Whipsaw After Russian Attack on Ukraine
description: Stocks in Europe were sharply lower, but the S&P 500 rebounded after an early decline. Energy markets swung wildly, and shares in Moscow collapsed.
content: Oil prices and global stock markets swung wildly on Thursday after Russia launched an invasion of Ukraine, raising fears of a wider economic crisis that could follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Is Your ‘Good Luck Charm’?
description: Do you have something that you believe brings you luck or that helps you feel focused or calm? What is the story behind it?
content: Above is a photo of Karen Chen, the 2017 U.S. national champion. She won a silver medal in the team event at the 2022 Winter Olympics after skating in the short program and the free skate. The red necklace she’s wearing, which has a rabbit made of jade, is a childhood gift from her mother. Ms. Chen says that she always wears it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: When starting their dance company L-E-V in 2013, the Israeli artists Sharon Eyal and Gai Behar signaled that it would be a heart-centered endeavor. After all, Lev means “heart” in Hebrew. Over the past five years, that intention has been explicitly realized with the creation of their “Love” trilogy. The first part came to New York in 2017, the second in 2019, and this week the series concludes with “Chapter 3: The Brutal Journey of the Heart” at the Joyce Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Pakistan’s leader is in Moscow to meet with Putin about a gas pipeline.
description: Prime Minister Imran Khan’s long-planned visit began hours before Russian forces attacked Ukraine.
content: Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan was due to meet President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow on Thursday during a long-planned visit that began hours before Russian forces attacked Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Ukrainians Abroad Talk of Shock and Disbelief as Homeland Is Invaded
description: Across Europe, Ukrainian expatriates looked on in horror at the scenes of destruction back home, and expressed feelings of hopelessness.
content: LONDON — Ukrainians living across Europe watched in horror and disbelief from afar on Thursday as Russia’s invasion of their home country began with shelling and rocket attacks in several cities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Bucolic Getaway in Texas, Complete With 19th-Century Bungalows
description: Plus: a kaiseki restaurant on the Lower East Side, a new line of eclectic wallpaper and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: The Chef, a Psychic, Didn’t Foresee Death in the Dining Room
description: In Valerie Wilson Wesley’s new novel, “A Fatal Glow,” a Realtor-turned-caterer investigates the death of an exceedingly unpleasant businessman.
content: Readers have a more sophisticated appreciation of Nordic crime fiction these days. They understand that lumping disparate authors and series by region can do a disservice to the individual works in question — not to mention to the locations. (Sweden is not Denmark is not Norway is not Iceland, after all.) For those in search of a new Danish series, Katrine Engberg’s three books featuring the Copenhagen detectives Jeppe Korner and Anette Werner will prove satisfying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Jonathan Weisman
title: Courting G.O.P.’s Mainstream and Extreme, McCarthy Plots Rise to Speaker
description: The top House Republican is attempting a series of political contortions to try to secure his place in a party that has shifted under his feet.
content: WASHINGTON — Over a breakfast of bacon and eggs in his California district last week, Representative Kevin McCarthy, the House Republican leader, tried to calm the nerves of a small group of longtime donors who raised questions about the extremists in his conference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Putin Is Teaching Us a Brutal Lesson About History
description: Vanity, viciousness and tribalism never go away.
content: What I see on the faces and hear in the voices of so many of the people around me is sheer disbelief about Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine and a brutal war in Europe: Aren’t we supposed to be past this? Didn’t history move on? The Wall came down, the Cold War ended, and democratic liberalism was the wave of the future, which wouldn’t be so kind to strongmen like Vladimir Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Ukraine’s military is badly outgunned by Russia despite the West’s support.
description: The country’s forces “will hold up as long as there are bullets,” a top general said in December. But, he added, “without delivery of reserves, there’s not an army in the world that can hold out.”
content: Even with the tons of weapons, ammunition and equipment delivered to Ukraine by Western allies in just the last few weeks, the Ukrainian military is outgunned by the larger, more technologically advanced Russian forces that have launched a multipronged invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Say Hello Again to the Office, Fingers Crossed
description: Antsy executives have a message for their employees: Plans to return to in-person work are real this time.
content: Executives at the investment firm TIAA are especially proud of one aspect of their back-to-work plans: The company is on only its second round of setting a return-to-office date. They first hoped to bring employees back in January, but were derailed by the Omicron variant. Now the firm is targeting March 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Guess Who’s Back on the Line
description: Hint: He likes you almost as much as he does Putin.
content: Hard to avoid thinking about Donald Trump when he’s calling Vladimir Putin’s current behavior “genius.” Just when you’re geared up to block the guy out of your life for a while, he makes a scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: From Thriller to Fantasy to Horror, the Genre Series Is the Cash Cow
description: All six of the novels that have entered the best-seller list this week are continuations of stories or characters readers have encountered before.
content: WORLD SERIES Of the six books that make their debuts on the hardcover fiction list this week — all in their first week on sale — not a single one is a stand-alone novel. Each of these new best sellers is part of a series, its story already long underway for readers before the book even hit shelves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Notes to a Teacher Lead Police to a Child’s Body
description: The mother of a student wrote that she was being held against her will at a house in Las Vegas and feared for her son, the authorities said.
content: A Las Vegas girl passed several notes to her elementary-school teacher on Tuesday morning. They were from the girl’s mother, and the contents were alarming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Three Months’ Review: A Refreshing Film Treatment of H.I.V.
description: This sensitive comedy by Jared Frieder sketches a relationship that blossoms in the shadow of not knowing.
content: It can take three months after exposure for the bloodstream to accumulate enough antibodies to test positive for human immunodeficiency virus, or H.I.V.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In a Texas Border Town, Democratic Officials Are Becoming Republicans
description: Democrats have long held local offices in Sanderson, a West Texas town of fewer than 1,000 people. Then top officials decided to leave the party.
content: SANDERSON, Texas — In a remote corner of West Texas along the Rio Grande, where cactuses far outnumber residents and the closest grocer is an hour’s drive, a quiet political upheaval has been taking place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Jurors have reached a verdict in the trial of three officers over George Floyd’s death.
description: ST. PAUL, Minn. — Jurors have reached a verdict after about 13 hours of weighing whether three former Minneapolis police officers violated George Floyd’s constitutional rights by not intervening to help him as he pleaded for air while Derek Chauvin knelt on his neck.
content: ST. PAUL, Minn. — Jurors have reached a verdict after about 13 hours of weighing whether three former Minneapolis police officers violated George Floyd’s constitutional rights by not intervening to help him as he pleaded for air while Derek Chauvin knelt on his neck.

author: By Abby Ellin
title: It’s No Longer Enough to Propose. Now We Party Too.
description: No, nothing is private anymore, not even one of the most consequential questions to ever be asked.
content: Matt Singh wanted to do something over the top when he proposed to his girlfriend, Rubbani Singh (they have the same last name). The couple had been together since high school, and it was hard to surprise each another.
source.name: The New York Times

title: UEFA will strip St. Petersburg of the Champions League final.
description: European soccer’s governing body will meet Friday to decide on a new site for the top club game of the season after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: European soccer’s governing body is convening an emergency meeting of its top board members on Friday after deciding to strip St. Petersburg, Russia, from hosting the Champions League final, the biggest club game of the year, after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: How Long Is Long Covid? How Long Would It Keep Him From Music?
description: A celebrated Broadway conductor caught Covid in the first wave. Two despairing years later, he is finally reclaiming his old life, breath by breath.
content: On the morning that Broadway shut down in March 2020, Joel Fram woke up feeling like a steamroller had rolled over him on its way somewhere else. He had a high fever, which evolved into a terrible sore throat and trouble breathing. Like countless other New Yorkers, Mr. Fram, the conductor of the Broadway show “Company,” had gotten Covid-19 in the city’s crushing first wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Queen Elizabeth cancels virtual events for the second time since testing positive.
description: The 95-year-old queen would be “continuing with light duties,” Buckingham Palace said, and she has no other engagements scheduled this week.
content: Queen Elizabeth II postponed her daily virtual engagements on Thursday, Buckingham Palace said, the second time she has taken such a step since she tested positive for the coronavirus on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden announces new sanctions: Putin and Russia ‘will bear the consequences’ of their war.
description: Mr. Biden said the United States would cut off Russia’s largest banks and largest companies from the western financial markets, freeze assets of Russian elites and restrict exports of technology to Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Thursday said the United States is imposing what he said would be crushing sanctions on Russia for waging war on Ukraine, denouncing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for launching a “brutal assault on the people of Ukraine” overnight.

content: PARIS — President Vladimir V. Putin has ordered Russian troops into Ukraine but made clear his true target goes beyond his neighbor to America’s “empire of lies,” and he threatened “consequences you have never faced in your history” for “anyone who tries to interfere with us.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: On London Stages, Maverick Responses to Mortality
description: Creative adaptations of “Wuthering Heights” and Ionesco’s “The Chairs” grapple with death and feature inclusions of the coronavirus and performance artists.
content: LONDON — The opportunity to see Kathryn Hunter in peak form is a rare treat, and one that is currently available by booking a seat for the Almeida Theater’s revival of “The Chairs.” This hugely gifted actress plays a character, billed as the Old Woman in Ionesco’s 1952 classic, with enough boundless wit and energy to make a mockery of age.

title: Abortion Pills Now Account for More Than Half of U.S. Abortions
description: The data, released in a report Thursday, is a sign that medication abortion has become the most accessible and preferred method for terminating pregnancy.
content: More than half of recent abortions in the United States were carried out with abortion pills, according to preliminary data released on Thursday, a sign that medication abortion has increasingly become the most accessible and preferred method for terminating pregnancy.

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Around the World, Buying Is Costlier Than Renting
description: A new study compares the costs of renting versus buying a three-bedroom home in 39 countries across the globe.
content: In today’s tight, competitive housing market, the first hurdle for many aspiring home buyers is simply being able to afford one. After all, a rent check is usually smaller than a mortgage payment on a comparable property. For those looking to buy a home overseas, the hurdles can get even higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: ‘The Desperate Hour’ Review: An Exercise in Panic
description: Naomi Watts plays a mother whose morning jog becomes a nightmare in this thriller from Phillip Noyce.
content: If your 84-minute movie about family trauma turns into a school-shooting thriller but that thriller is also about the family’s mother having the worst jog of her life and that jog includes dozens of phone calls to and from 9-1-1, it doesn’t need a director. It needs a life coach and a personal trainer. The audience, meanwhile, needs a hostage negotiator. That mom? She basically becomes one, too. And because Naomi Watts plays her, it seemed fair to assume that Amy’s helplessness would achieve more than this single note. But nope.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 12 Ways to Cook Up a Delicious Mardi Gras

content: At Sotheby’s on Wednesday night, a single lot of NFTs — 104 digital art assets known as CryptoPunks — was expected to sell for as much as $30 million. But after a delay of 25 minutes past the auction’s expected start time, the sale was off.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine caused a surge in energy prices on Thursday, adding to worries over tight supplies and raising fresh questions about the flows of oil and gas from Russia into Europe in the months ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inflation fears could limit the U.S. sanctions response to Russia’s Ukraine invasion.

content: “I just want to say, I am so happy that Mom did not die of Covid,” says Bobby Worth (Henry Winkler) in “Family Squares,” a film told through FaceTime, Zoom and phone calls immediately before and after the death of the Worth family matriarch, Mabel (June Squibb).

author: By Gisela Williams and Allegra Martin
title: In Naples, a 19th-Century Palace Passed Down for Generations
description: An elaborate gift from a king to his wife, Villa Lucia has enraptured for decades, and the home’s current inhabitants are continuing the love affair.
content: IN THE HEART of Naples, Italy, a city whose peeling jewel-toned apartment buildings and Baroque churches often call to mind a faded but still glorious opera set, there is a 25-acre private park so lush and tranquil, it feels more like an enchanted woodland. Though it is mostly wild — a tangle of holm oaks, palms and flowering acanthuses intersected by a few winding trails — at its center is a romantic neo-Classical marble fountain carved in the early 1800s. Positioned above a shallow pool, two winged figures — Hymen, the ancient Greek god of marriage ceremonies, and Eros, the mischievous god of carnal desire — gaze at each other over a decorative urn. “Both the stillness of this place and this fountain are so sacred to me,” says the artist and jewelry designer Margherita Marzotto, 32, admiring the work as if for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Where the Criminal and Civil Investigations Into Donald Trump Stand
description: One of the highest profile investigations into the former president appeared to stall on Wednesday, but several other inquiries are in progress around the country.
content: The abrupt resignation of the two prosecutors leading the Manhattan district attorney’s investigation into Donald J. Trump leaves the future of the inquiry, which had been put on a monthlong pause, in doubt.

title: Art Briles, Who Coached Baylor During Sexual Assault Scandal, Is Hired at Grambling State
description: Grambling State officials said they did not plan to formally discuss the reason for bringing Briles back into college football after Baylor fired him in 2016.
content: Art Briles, the former Baylor football coach who was fired in 2016 after a university investigation found that he and other coaches botched sexual assault accusations levied against football players, was hired Thursday as Grambling State University’s offensive coordinator, school officials said.

title: Avian Flu Spread in the U.S. Worries Poultry Industry
description: Though the risk to humans is low, scientists warn that outbreaks among farmed birds increase the potential for the virus to mutate and pose a threat to humans.

author: By Eric Asimov

title: Marta Sánchez Finds Beauty in Loss With a Refreshed Quintet

content: As the number of coronavirus cases continues to decline and warm weather starts to peek through the wintry gray, promising flashes of normal life have begun to reappear in New York City.

title: 14 New Books Coming in March
description: Memoirs from Sarah Polley and Bill Barr, new novels from NoViolet Bulawayo, Claire-Louise Bennett and Pankaj Mishra, and plenty more.
content: Growing up, Newton was immersed in fabulous family lore. There was the relative who married 13 times and the one who killed a man with a hay hook; her own mother performed exorcisms in the living room. Perhaps unsurprisingly, Newton has been writing about genealogy for years. But a family story isn’t just about the people (even when they’re this colorful), and Newton touches on intergenerational trauma, mental illness, the influence of religion and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Just Because a Number Is Available Doesn’t Mean You Can Have It
description: Honoring Paul O’Neill’s No. 21 elevates him in Monument Park but removes him from an odd fraternity of players whose numbers are out of circulation but have not been officially retired.
content: For Morgan Ensberg, damage control started when he saw his uniform number at spring training in 2008. It was 21, the number worn by Paul O’Neill for nine sterling seasons in pinstripes, and after six years out of circulation, the Yankees had decided to quietly reintroduce it. Big mistake, Ensberg thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city, is a major target of Russia. Here’s why.
description: In the Kremlin’s view, the city demonstrates the folly of Ukraine trying to live apart from Russia.
content: Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city and a major target of Russia’s invading forces, has a special place in the Kremlin’s version of history, which portrays it as the place that demonstrates the folly of Ukraine trying to live apart from Russia.
