author: By Wesley Morris
title: ‘Studio 666’ Review: Foo Fighting the Devil
description: The band members play themselves in this horror comedy from BJ McDonnell. But the gore overtakes the (limited) fun.
content: It isn’t always enough for a lousy horror comedy to splash around in its lousiness. But I’d like to thank the people who made “Studio 666.” They’ve splashed me — with the blood of food-delivery guys and the viscera of Chris Shiflett, the chief guitarist of Foo Fighters until he meets his end here, and with the wink-wink nastiness that lightens all of the excess. (This thing is too long and cover-your-eyes gory.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: As the E.U. weighs new sanctions on Russia, it’s considering omitting Putin for now.
description: Some members, including Germany, advocated not including him so that dialogue was still possible with Russia’s top leadership.
content: BRUSSELS — European Union ambassadors in Brussels moved closer to consensus on a significant package of sanctions targeting broad sectors of the Russian economy and individuals on Thursday, but were debating whether to keep President Vladimir V. Putin off their list for now, diplomats who participated in or were briefed on the talks said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Sad Coda for Lovelorn Octogenarians Who Absconded Through Outback
description: Terry Gibbs was apprehended after abducting his longtime partner from her nursing home and setting out on a 3,000-mile journey. Seven weeks later, they died two days apart.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was a journey that seemed doomed from the start: An octogenarian couple, one spiriting the other away from a residential care home in a white Mazda pickup, the breadth of the treacherous Australian outback laid out before them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Farah Stockman, Ross Douthat and Frank Bruni
title: Four Times Opinion Writers Analyze Russia’s Invasion: ‘The World Has Changed Overnight’
description: Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Farah Stockman, Ross Douthat and Frank Bruni discuss a dark moment for Ukraine, Europe and the world.
content: Russian troops invaded Ukraine on Thursday, attacking over a dozen major cities and towns, including the capital, Kyiv. The attacks began the first major land war in Europe in decades. “This aggression cannot go unanswered,” President Biden said as he announced harsh sanctions against Russia, including blocking major Russian banks and “corrupt billionaires” from access to the U.S. financial system as well as deploying troops to NATO’s eastern flank. Times Opinion writers Farah Stockman, Frank Bruni and Ross Douthat discuss what’s to come with Times Opinion podcast host Lulu Garcia-Navarro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsea Garrison, Clare Toeniskoetter, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Sydney Harper, Lisa Chow, Larissa Anderson, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Russian Invasion Begins
description: In the hours before the assault and during the attack itself, we heard from our correspondents in the Ukrainian cities of Kyiv and Slovyansk, and in Moscow.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Putin Spins a Conspiracy Theory That Ukraine Is on a Path to Nuclear Weapons
description: Russia’s president has made such arguments before, but usually as asides — not as the justification for urgent action in Ukraine.
content: MUNICH — When Ukraine gave up a huge arsenal of nuclear weapons left on its territory after the collapse of the Soviet Union, it famously struck a deal with Washington, London and Moscow, trading the weapons for a guarantee of its security and borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: James Inhofe, Oklahoma Senator, Is Said to Plan an Early Retirement
description: The 87-year-old Republican has told people that he will step down at the end of the year, four years before his term is up. His seat is likely to stay in G.O.P. hands.
content: Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma, has told officials in his state that he will step down at the end of this Congress, vacating a seat he has held since 1994 with four years remaining in his term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘Careless Crime’ Review: A Time Loop in Iran
description: Shahram Mokri’s film bends time and space as it considers events from 40 years earlier, when an arson attack on a movie theater set off the Iranian Revolution.
content: In the films of the Iranian director Shahram Mokri, time ripples, bends, devours itself. Mokri’s prior features, “Fish & Cat” and “Invasion,” have ouroboros-style plots, with recursive chronologies and scenes repeated from various characters’ points of view. His latest, “Careless Crime,” pivots on another kind of time loop: the repetitions of history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Fox News hosts play down Russia’s attack on Ukraine.
description: Comments made by the stars of the network's prime-time opinion programs came in contrast to coverage by its correspondents reporting from Ukraine.
content: As Russia began an invasion into Ukraine, the Fox News host Laura Ingraham on Wednesday night welcomed a call in to her show from former President Donald J. Trump, who blamed the “weakness and the incompetence” of the Biden administration for the military strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolina Ebeid and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: Albeit
description: Carolina Ebeid’s spring-ish poem is filled with mysteries, starting with the title and first line that launch us in medias res, making us feel as if we’re eavesdropping.
content: Carolina Ebeid’s spring-ish poem is filled with mysteries, starting with the title and first line that launch us in medias res, making us feel as if we’re eavesdropping. A few lines down, a “bee-hive made of glass” becomes “An observatory/of translucent arteries/lit with wing-gossip.” I admire how this poem moves in strange but wholly natural ways, shifting from the hive to something larger. The final three lines are unexpected and remind me how enjoyable it can be to follow a poet into her own particular Eden. Selected by Victoria Chang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Antiquities Valued at More Than $20 Million Returned to Greece
description: The 55 items seized by the Manhattan district attorney’s office are thought to have been stolen from archaeological sites and illegally brought into the United States.
content: The gold brooch from ancient Greece was valued at $1.3 million. A 3,500-year-old coffin the size of a trunk, known as a larnax and decorated with undulating patterns, was valued at $1 million. But the most distinctive of the 55 antiquities returned to Greece by the Manhattan district attorney’s office this week was a 2,500-year-old sculpture of an athletic youth, known as a kouros, valued at $14 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Considers Trump’s Putin Praise
description: Meyers joked that Trump “narrates Putin’s every move like he is Tony Romo calling the last drive of a playoff game.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: Long Island, We Need to Talk (About Housing)
description: Long Island needs more housing. The state needs to change the rules.
content: HUNTINGTON, N.Y. — After four decades of unprincipled opposition, this affluent suburb on Long Island’s northern shore agreed in December to allow the construction of 146 subsidized town homes and apartments on a scrubby lot next to an electrical substation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Facebook Will Make You Love Reels
description: Shoving these videos at us is a little bit sad, a little bit brilliant — and very much worth watching.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Is There Such a Thing as Black Thought?
description: In an uncategorizable new musical, “Black No More,” the rapper Tariq Trotter investigates Black identity — a matter that has occupied his whole career.
content: Tariq Trotter — the rapper who fronts the legendary hip-hop band the Roots — pulled up to the Pershing Square Signature Theater on 42nd Street in Manhattan, where he was rehearsing for the new Off Broadway musical “Black No More.” He drove a black sedan that reminded me of the Batmobile — suitable for an artist who goes by the nom de guerre Black Thought, the name of a bearded Negro superhero if ever there was one. Five minutes earlier, Trotter had sent me a text: “Stay around. I have some music I want to play for you.” The city was dark and quiet, and I climbed into a car whose make I didn’t know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: How Should the World Respond to Russia’s Assault on Ukraine?
description: President Biden announced a “devastating packages of sanctions” on Russia. Will they be enough to save Ukraine’s sovereignty?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. Starting next week, the newsletter will be sent once a week on Wednesdays. You can sign up here to receive it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Burning Sea’ Review: Smoke on the Water
description: An oil-rig accident in the North Sea kicks off this well-acted, pleasantly predictable survival thriller.
content: Even allowing for the elastic credibility standards of the average survival movie, “The Burning Sea” is a stretch. (A favorite moment is when the unconscious half of the central couple pops awake at an especially critical juncture.) Yet if the machinations of the plot are a tad rickety, its geologic premise is inarguably stable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: The U.N. Security Council met to prevent military action by Putin. Russia invaded Ukraine as they spoke.
description: The United States said the Council would meet on Thursday to vote on a resolution condemning Russia’s actions.
content: The United Nations Security Council held an emergency meeting late Wednesday in the hopes of stopping President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia from invading Ukraine. Instead, his country did just that while they were delivering their speeches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Anita Hill Takes On Those ‘Trying to Put Black Women in a Box’
description: The law professor who testified during Justice Clarence Thomas’s confirmation 30 years ago reflects on what hasn’t changed about the American judiciary.
content: President Biden has interviewed at least three candidates for the Supreme Court seat vacated by Justice Stephen Breyer and has committed to nominating a Black woman to fill it. As the country awaits his selection, Kara Swisher turns to the law professor Anita Hill — host of the new podcast “Getting Even” — who testified during Clarence Thomas’s confirmation 30 years ago, accusing him of sexual harassment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Dan Bilefsky
title: Thousands of Russians protest President Vladimir V. Putin’s assault on Ukraine. Some chant: ‘No to war!
description: At the demonstrations, many people said they felt depressed and broken by the news of Russian military action.
content: Thousands of protesters took to the streets and squares of Russian cities on Thursday to protest President Vladimir V. Putin’s decision to invade Ukraine, only to be met with heavy police presence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Servants’ Review: Fighting for Purity of Faith
description: Teenage priests in training resist the mingling of church and the Communist state in Ivan Ostrochovsky’s drama.
content: The captivating ecclesiastical drama “Servants,” set in 1980s Czechoslovakia, follows teenage matriculates at a Christian seminary who awaken to a grim reality. Their Dean (Vladimir Strnisko) is a member of Pacem in Terris, a group of clergy quietly granting control of the church to the Communist state. Considering this a moral corruption, several of the students initiate a discreet rebellion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A Winter Storm Will Dump Snow and Ice From Texas to Maine
description: Parts of New England may see a foot of snow while dangerous ice accumulations in the Southern Plains and the Mid-Atlantic could cause power outages, meteorologists said.
content: A significant winter storm began to batter the Southern Plains up to the Ohio Valley on Thursday night before it was expected to move over the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast regions on Friday, creating dangerous travel conditions and raising the risk of widespread power outages, meteorologists said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Carries Out First Airstrike in Somalia Since August
description: The strike targeted Al Shabab militants who had attacked allied Somali security forces.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States conducted a drone strike against Al Shabab militants in Somalia this week, the first such military action against the Qaeda affiliate in East Africa since August, the military’s Africa Command said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Marshall Sues Conference USA Among Latest Spats in Realignment
description: Several universities that are choosing to switch leagues are attempting to do so ahead of timelines outlined by their conference’s contracts.
content: Marshall University filed a lawsuit against Conference USA on Tuesday to speed up its move to the Sun Belt Conference, the Division I conference that the university plans to join by the summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: You May Sound Silly, but Don’t Be Afraid to Order a Grasshopper
description: The green, creamy, minty drink of decades past is back, and spreading its wings in creative new variations.
content: A request for a Grasshopper cocktail these days is a drama with two distinct acts. First comes the order, accompanied by giggles and a sense that one is knowingly indulging in a bit of retro kitsch. Second comes the flash of unexpected delight — surprise that an old fuddy-duddy cocktail your grandparents drank could taste so good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Neil MacFarquhar
title: Putin Announces Start to ‘Military Operation’ Against Ukraine
description: “The invasion has begun,” Ukraine’s Interior Ministry said. Putin says he seeks “demilitarization” of Ukraine but has no plans to occupy it.
content: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia declared the start of a “special military operation” in Ukraine on Thursday, after months of speculation about Russia’s intentions as it massed tens of thousands of troops on Ukraine’s border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Burned Popcorn
description: Is it really a French thing?
content: Lucy writes: My husband burns his microwave popcorn on purpose. He says it’s French, but I doubt it. It’s annoying because of the smell. Could you please tell him this isn’t a thing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Butter’ Review: High-Stakes Popularity
description: Fed up with his classmates’ contempt, an obese high school student decides he’ll gorge himself to death on New Year’s Eve.
content: Why do movies that take on bullying so often fetishize the very acts they seem to be critiquing? “Butter,” directed by Paul A. Kaufman — who adapted Erin Jade Lange’s young adult novel — seems to wallow in the brutality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Monika Pronczuk
title: U.S. troops in Poland prepare for the arrival of refugees from Ukraine.
description: Polish officials say their border is open and they are ready to provide shelter to anyone fleeing the conflict.
content: U.S. Army troops are preparing to move closer to Poland’s border with Ukraine to help process people fleeing the country after Russia launched an all-out assault, an Army spokesman said on Thursday, as Poland said it was ready to provide shelter to anyone fleeing the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns and Madeline Cass
title: You Can Learn to Love Being Alone
description: Solitude doesn’t have to feel lonely. It can be restoring and refreshing with a little practice.
content: Sally Snowman loves to be alone. As the keeper of Boston Light, a centuries-old lighthouse on Little Brewster Island in Boston Harbor, she’s had a lot of practice. For most of the last 19 years, she’s lived there from April through October.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
description: Bruckner, Henze, Price, Schubert and a trailblazing cellist are among the recent highlights.
content: Anton Bruckner, modernist trailblazer? So thinks François-Xavier Roth, one of the more inventive conductors working today. Roth has been working on a Bruckner cycle with his Gürzenich Orchestra in Cologne, Germany, of which this is the first evidence on record. To illustrate the composer’s progressivism in concert Roth, has performed the Third Symphony with Ligeti, the Eighth with Lachenmann and this Seventh, which was taped live in December 2019, with music by Graciane Finzi. The pairing doesn’t make it to disc; what is left is Bruckner quite different from the norm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haley Willis, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Masha Froliak
title: Russian helicopters attack an airport near Kyiv.
description: Footage verified by The Times shows the most intense fighting seen so far near Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.
content: Footage verified by The Times shows the most intense fighting seen so far near Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv. At least a half dozen Russian helicopters were spotted flying west over the Dnieper river toward Hostomel, a town on the outskirts of the city. Other videos capture the helicopters attacking Hostomel’s airport. One video, released by Ukraine’s armed forces, appears to show at least one of those helicopters being shot down.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Sleepless Nights in Moscow as a Nation Lurches Toward Conflict
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, February 24, 2022.
content: “This hatred that you could read in him so clearly, it wasn’t fake. This is not a game.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 24, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Feb. 24, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about a plan by Mayor Eric Adams to suspend the expansion of New York’s composting program referred incorrectly to methane. It is far more potent than carbon dioxide, not carbon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: A Blow to the Manhattan Case Against Trump
description: The longstanding criminal investigation is thrown into doubt after a monthlong pause and questions about the Manhattan district attorney’s commitment.
content: Good morning. Today we’ll look at a sudden blow to the criminal investigation of former President Donald J. Trump in Manhattan, and the promise of safety barriers for some subway platforms after a fatal shoving death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Creation Stories’ Review: The Man Behind a Raucous Record Label
description: A rock ’n’ roll biopic about Creation Records, which gave us Oasis, My Bloody Valentine and more.
content: There’s a poem in which the British writer and musician Martin Newell turns the name of a superstar 1960s guitarist into a verb. Like so:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard N. Haass
title: The West Must Show Putin How Wrong He Is to Choose War
description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine calls for a determined, comprehensive response.
content: The moment, after a standoff stretching for months, has arrived. Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is underway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Patrick J. Lyons
title: Is the BA.2 version of Omicron worse? Here’s what you need to know.
description: As the highly contagious Omicron variant of the coronavirus has become dominant worldwide, more attention is being paid to a less common Omicron subvariant that appears to be even more transmissible.
content: With the huge Omicron surge in coronavirus cases now receding in the United States and many other countries, reports have been cropping up in many news outlets lately about a potentially worrisome new version of Omicron — a subvariant known as BA.2 — and the threats it may pose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: A Pianist Strolls Her Harlem History, and Scott Joplin’s
description: Lara Downes’s latest album, “Reflections: Scott Joplin Reconsidered,” is inspired by the fact that Joplin’s achievement remains fuzzy to many.
content: Not long before his death in 1917, Scott Joplin predicted that he would become a fixture of the American musical canon. A colleague later recalled him saying, “When I’m dead 25 years, people are going to begin to recognize me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin announces a ‘military operation’ in Ukraine as the U.N. Security Council pleads with him to pull back.
description: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia declared the start of a “special military operation” in Ukraine, pledging he would seek to demilitarize but not occupy the country, addressing the nation in a televised speech broadcast just before 6 a.m. local time.
content: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia declared the start of a “special military operation” in Ukraine, pledging he would seek to demilitarize but not occupy the country, addressing the nation in a televised speech broadcast just before 6 a.m. local time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google eases pandemic rules for employees in the U.S.
description: The company also said it would restore many of its famed office perks.
content: As Google prepares to bring workers back to its offices, the company is relaxing some of its Covid-19 workplace policies, including a rule requiring U.S. employees to be vaccinated. But workers will still have to be vaccinated if they plan to use the company’s offices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
title: Accurate U.S. intelligence did not stop Putin, but it gave Biden big advantages.
description: The depth and quality of the intelligence strengthened the president’s hand in persuading allies to form a unified front against Moscow.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States intelligence agencies unearthed Russia’s war plans. They accurately assessed President Vladimir V. Putin’s intentions and, through strategic public releases of information, complicated his efforts to create a pretext to send his armed forces into Ukraine. They got the timing of his invasion right almost to the hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: ‘We do not expect anyone to fight for us,’ Ukraine’s defiant ambassador says from Washington.
description: Ms. Marakova said that Ukrainian forces had destroyed two Russian helicopters just outside of Kyiv, and seven aircraft in unspecific locations.
content: WASHINGTON — Ukraine’s ambassador to Washington pleaded for help from the world, saying that at least 40 Ukrainian troops have already been killed by Russia, along with “dozens” of Ukrainian civilians, and that the site of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster was under attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Can a Cool Bar Make It in Rockefeller Center?
description: The guys behind the Smile and Ray’s are opening Pebble Bar in touristy Midtown. Celebrity friends like Pete Davidson and Nicholas Braun are investors.
content: The four-story townhouse at the corner of West 49th Street and the Avenue of the Americas has stood there for more than a century, much of it as a fabled Irish saloon named Hurley’s, which survived Prohibition and the development of Rockefeller Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Michael Downey and Taras Ratushnyy
title: ‘I fear for my kids.’ Ukrainians in Kyiv flee the capital.
description: Chernihiv lies in the path of advancing Russian forces and sits in the path of the only road down from the border to Kyiv.
content: As Ukrainians woke up to the noise of the Russian bombardment across the country, many began to flee westward to escape the advancement of Russian troops. Times video journalists spoke to residents crossing the Dnieper River through Kyiv in cars. Buses and cars packed with family members, pets and personal belongings were backed up for miles. Anna, a resident of Chernihiv, was stuck in traffic with her husband and three children — two in another car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Friday Briefing: Fierce Fighting Across Ukraine
description: Russians took Chernobyl, Ukraine said, and the U.S. Pentagon gave a grim assessment.
content: Less than a day after Russian forces attacked Ukraine on all sides, setting off intense fighting around the country, President Biden said from the White House that it was a “dangerous moment for all of Europe,” and that President Vladimir Putin of Russia had “unleashed a great pain.” Here are the latest updates, a map of the war and a guide to its causes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: William Kuenzel, Who Claimed Innocence From Death Row, Dies at 60
description: When evidence emerged that might have exonerated him, his case drew the support of prominent legal figures, but the Supreme Court twice declined to review it.
content: William Kuenzel, a prisoner whose unsuccessful challenges to his murder conviction in 1988 attracted support from prominent but disparate legal figures — including the conservative former U.S. Attorney General Edwin C. Meese III and Robert M. Morgenthau, Manhattan’s liberal, longest-serving district attorney — died on Saturday at the William C. Holman Correctional Institution in Atmore, Ala. He was 60 and had been on death row for 34 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: The Invasion of Ukraine: How Russia Attacked and What Happens Next
description: Explosions thundered in Ukrainian cities shortly after President Vladimir V. Putin declared the start of a “special military operation.”
content: After months of troop and tank buildups, of grim warnings of violence and vague assurances of peace, and of efforts at diplomacy in Washington, the halls of the United Nations and the capitals of Europe, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine began early Thursday morning, with shelling and rocket attacks on several major cities including the capital, Kyiv, and dozens of deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Zelensky Steps Into a Role Few Expected: Ukraine’s Wartime President
description: Even as doubts have lingered about his preparedness to lead, Volodymyr Zelensky, a former actor, gave the performance of his life as Russian forces prepared to invade.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — He appeared on Ukrainian television early on Thursday morning, as the threat of war was pressing down. First, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addressed the 44 million citizens of Ukraine. Then he turned to the 144 million Russians living next door and beseeched them to prevent an attack that evoked the darkest eras in Europe since World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Roman Mosaics Point to Rowdy London District’s High-End Side
description: The discovery of the two mosaics in Southwark, across the Thames from the City of London, has been greeted by archaeologists as “exceptional.”
content: LONDON — The Southwark district in London during the Roman era is often presented as little more than a patch of swampy land lined with low-end brothels, taverns, and gambling joints. But two newly discovered mosaics in the district south of the Thames are adding to evidence that it also had a more upmarket side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: U.S. announces sweeping restrictions on technological exports to Russia.
description: The moves are aimed at cutting off Russia from critical technology needed to power its military and economy.
content: The Biden administration on Thursday announced a series of restrictions aimed at cutting off Russia’s access to foreign products like semiconductors, computers, lasers and telecommunications equipment in response to its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: M.L.B. Tells Union Games Will Be Lost Without a Deal Soon
description: The league said it would begin canceling games if a collective bargaining agreement was not reached by Monday. The sides are negotiating this week in Florida.
content: JUPITER, Fla. — With the scheduled start of the 2022 regular season approaching and little progress made toward a new collective bargaining agreement despite face-to-face negotiations this week, Major League Baseball reiterated its position — and its threat — to the players’ union on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: A Group Founded by Colin Kaepernick Is Providing Free Second Autopsies
description: The examinations by board-certified forensic pathologists will be available for the families of people who died in police-related circumstances.
content: A group founded by the former N.F.L. quarterback Colin Kaepernick started this week to offer free secondary autopsies for families of people who died under “police-related” circumstances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Melissa Eddy
title: Multinationals halt operations in Ukraine and move employees to safety.
description: The swiftness of Russia’s assault raised questions about how to confront the rapidly shifting geopolitical landscape.
content: Multinational corporations began closing their operations in Ukraine and moving employees to safety on Thursday, as executives grappled with the implications of a full-scale invasion by Russia and the impact of widely swinging stock and commodity prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: England is Living with the Virus
description: Boris Johnson scrapped the remaining restrictions.
content: This week Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced that he was scrapping the remaining coronavirus restrictions in England, saying it was time to live with the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: The Pentagon orders another 7,000 American troops to Europe.
description: The deployment will bring to 14,000 the number of American troops that President Biden has ordered to Europe since the Ukraine crisis began.
content: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon said on Thursday that it was sending an additional 7,000 troops to Europe, after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine launched the biggest land war in Europe since World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: History and modernity duke it out in this week’s recommended titles. In history’s corner, we have the heavyweight tag team of Watergate and the Civil War, with Garrett M. Graff writing about the scandal that brought down Richard Nixon’s presidency and David Wright Faladé writing a historical novel, “Black Cloud Rising,” about the real-life African Brigade and the Black soldiers who fought in it. In modernity’s corner, Johann Hari looks at the ways information overload destroys our focus, and Sequoia Nagamatsu imagines a world coping with a viral pandemic by way of robotic pets and euthanasia amusement parks. (And to think the plague used to be a historical subject!) Elsewhere, Imani Perry bridges the past and the present with a tour through the American South, Rachel Hawkins delivers a fun thriller set on a remote tropical island, and we recommend novels out of Chile and Japan. Happy reading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Brooke
title: How ‘Pam & Tommy’ Made Pamela Anderson Look Believable
description: The sixth episode of the Hulu series presents Pam as she delivers a testimony in a look carefully considered by the show’s costume, makeup and hair teams.
content: When it comes to appearing in court, clothes are a reliable tool for conveying a person’s character and values. Consider Elizabeth Holmes’s neutral, relatable, turtleneck-free makeover before her fraud trial, or the pristine white turtleneck dress and taupe Birkin bag that Cardi B wore to reject a plea deal in a misdemeanor assault case, simultaneously signaling innocence with her color palette and reminding the crowd of her professional success with her very expensive purse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: 11,000 Free Pairs of Shoes Will Dance Across New York
description: The creative reuse center Materials for the Arts is working with the Joyce Theater and Karen Brooks Hopkins, the former BAM president, to distribute dance shoes at no cost.
content: Last week, 11,000 pairs of dance shoes made a long trek, all the way from Rhode Island to Queens. They arrived on busy Northern Boulevard in a 56-foot tractor-trailer full of 20 pallets, each holding 500 to 600 pairs. Their worth was estimated at around $300,000. But you can’t pin a price on dance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: CPAC: A Bacchanal of Right-Wing Pageantry, Passion and Grievance
description: CPAC was once about conservatism. Now it’s just Trump.
content: While U.S. leaders are dealing with war in Europe and disruption of the global order, the leading lights of MAGA America are in central Florida this week for that annual bacchanal of right-wing pageantry and passion known as the Conservative Political Action Conference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Eric Schmitt and Edward Wong
title: Beyond the Battlefield: What Might Happen Next in the Ukraine Crisis
description: Europe faces a new refugee crisis, and harsh economic penalties to punish Russia are expected to reverberate worldwide.
content: WASHINGTON — Much of the world woke up on Thursday to the specter of an all-out war in Europe after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia ordered his troops to invade Ukraine. That left millions of people — in Ukraine and Eastern Europe, but also in the United States and elsewhere — wondering how the conflict would affect their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘Hellbender’ Review: The Family That Preys Together
description: In a horror feature by a family of filmmakers, a young woman discovers her mother has been stifling her supernatural abilities.
content: In the last two years, The Adams family — Toby Poser, her husband, John Adams, and their daughters, Zelda and Lulu — began producing lo-fi rock under the band name H6LLB6ND6R and made “Hellbender,” their sixth feature film together. Poser, Zelda and John co-wrote and co-directed the film, and all the family members had acting roles. The music project inspired the movie project, an act of true collaboration that saw Poser, Zelda and John trading places in front of and behind the camera to execute their vision. Many scenes were devised ad hoc, as inspiration struck. While the result is a mostly-compelling tale of matriarchal megalomania, occasionally this group composition feels more like a jumble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: ‘I abandoned everything and left’: Ukrainians flee ahead of the Russian advance.
description: Civilians tried to escape eastern Ukraine, sharing jammed highways with military convoys, leaving homes, pets and belongings behind in a search for safety.
content: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — By the time she had packed her important documents, some clothes and a spare tire, and said goodbye to her dog, Maryna Danyliuk could tell the fighting was in the streets of her hometown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Valery Gergiev, a Putin Supporter, Will Not Conduct at Carnegie Hall
description: The star maestro, scheduled to lead three high-profile Vienna Philharmonic concerts this week, will not appear after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: Carnegie Hall and the Vienna Philharmonic announced on Thursday that the Russian conductor Valery Gergiev, a friend and prominent supporter of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, would no longer lead a series of concerts there this week amid growing international condemnation of Mr. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Survivors of Deadly Night at Greek Border Say They Were Left to Die
description: The four men recalled a night of exhaustion, cold and fear when 19 died after being forced across the Turkish border.
content: EDIRNE, Turkey — It was a cold night, lashing with rain and with a sharp north wind blowing, when Greek border forces pushed up to 50 migrants back across the river that marks the border with Turkey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Won’t My Boyfriend Shut Up About How Much He Loves His Ex?
description: A woman is hurt by the affection her partner expresses for his ex-wife on social media, but he says he can post whatever he wants.
content: My boyfriend and I have been dating seriously for two years. He was previously married for 25 years; he and his ex-wife divorced nine years ago and have two adult kids. They have a great relationship. But I dislike his frequent posts on social media that reminisce about falling in love with her — what she was wearing the first time he saw her, for instance — and how much he loves her still. These posts often include hearts and kissing emojis. I told him they are hurtful to me, but he says he’s free to post anything he wants on social media. He also says he loves me and that’s all that matters. Thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William P. Davis
title: A New California Law Could Make Your Next Car Rental More Expensive
description: For more than 30 years, California had prohibited rental car companies from charging for additional drivers. Not anymore.
content: Californians renting cars may want to watch out for new charges on their bill now that a longstanding provision banning fees for additional drivers has quietly been removed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Give It a Twirl!
description: Jake Halperin’s theme falls trippingly on the tongue.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — If I had a nickel for every time someone under the age of 30 told me that I was pronouncing the acronym “GIF” incorrectly, I would be a very wealthy person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Russians Now See a New Side to Putin: Dragging Them Into War
description: The autocrat who has steered Russia for 22 years was embraced by many Russians for what they saw as his rationality and astute risk management. That image has been upended.
content: MOSCOW — Russians thought they knew their president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Five Ways to Cook a Can of Chickpeas
description: Whether you eat them plain, roasted, simmered, fried or puréed, the possibilities are endless.
content: I’m constantly reconsidering and reorganizing my pantry, but there are a few things I like to keep well stocked regardless of the season: lentils and dried beans, canned coconut and canned tomatoes, nuts and nut butters, etc.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Can New Yorkers Be Lured Back to the Arts by a Good Deal?
description: With two-for-one cocktails at the Met museum and two-for-one Broadway tickets, New York arts institutions are trying to lure back locals after a long, tough winter.
content: The sounds of a small jazz combo filled the Great Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art last Saturday evening. Warm candles lit the space. Over at the museum’s American Wing Café, Christa Chiao and Anna Lee Hirschi were sipping prosecco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Catie Edmondson
title: Biden, vowing to hold Russia accountable, plans to announce ‘severe sanctions’ today.
description: Mr. Biden vowed to punish Moscow for “a premeditated war that will bring a catastrophic loss of life and human suffering.”
content: President Biden plans to impose what he called “severe sanctions” against Russia on Thursday during a public address on the Russian invasion of Ukraine, as explosions rocked cities across the country and signaled what the president described as an “unprovoked and unjustified attack.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: War in Ukraine
description: Russia has launched a major invasion. Here’s the latest.
content: The most significant European war in almost 80 years has begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: A Top Labor Official Joins Greenpeace USA.
description: The move by Tefere Gebre, the No. 3 official at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., highlights what many labor and environmental officials say is a need to cooperate.
content: Signaling the growing importance of ties between labor and environmental organizers on climate change, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.’s third-ranking official has announced that he was leaving to join Greenpeace USA.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Russia invades Ukraine.
content: Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, early this morning declared the start of a “special military operation” in Ukraine. Minutes later, large explosions were visible near Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city. Blasts were reported in Kyiv, the capital, and other parts of the country. Ukraine’s Interior Ministry said that Russian troops had landed in Odessa and were crossing the border. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Schwendener
title: Rashaad Newsome Pulls Out All the Stops
description: His protean “Assembly,” at the Park Avenue Armory, bridges art, technology, performance, workshops — and offers an A.I. Being who will teach you how to vogue.
content: One of Rashaad Newsome’s greatest contributions to contemporary art has been to highlight and champion vogueing — a stylized form of dance invented by pioneers of Black and trans culture whose ideas have gone mainstream in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Ukraine Invasion Has the Fed on Alert, but Not Changing Course
description: Central bankers are poised to raise interest rates in March. The Russian invasion of Ukraine poses a risk to economic growth but will likely exacerbate inflation.
content: Federal Reserve officials are turning a wary eye to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, though several have signaled in recent days that geopolitical tensions are unlikely to keep them from pulling back their support for the U.S. economy when the job market is booming and prices are climbing rapidly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | March 2, 2022
description: What is the best way to rank countries competing in the Olympics based on the medals they won?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Edward Wong
title: New U.S. Sanctions Target Russian Company Behind Lucrative Pipeline
description: The move by President Biden came as administration officials warned that a Russian military assault on Ukraine could be imminent.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Wednesday that he would issue economic sanctions on the company behind a new natural gas pipeline between Russia and Germany, the latest in a series of penalties that the White House has promised will continue as Russia escalates hostilities against Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Beyond the Statistics in Pedestrian Deaths’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about pedestrian safety in a reporter’s neighborhood in Albuquerque. Then, they will analyze a graph and consider how this issue affects their community.
content: This lesson is a part of our Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Motavalli
title: You Can Take It With You, if the Grave Is Deep Enough
description: Sometimes apocryphal, often outrageous: stories of car lovers who were buried with their prized possessions.
content: Yes, people can and do get buried in their cars. But you can’t always accept the claims at face value. A viral story in 2018 told of a Nigerian man who had buried his father in a BMW. According to The Standard, a Kenyan newspaper, it was “a dignified send-off befitting of his status.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: With ‘Cyrano,’ James McAvoy Is Savoring a ‘Purer Form of Storytelling’
description: The actor will be making his New York stage debut with Jamie Lloyd’s Olivier Award-winning production, coming in April to the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
content: LONDON — In a cozy upstairs bar at the Harold Pinter Theater here, the actor James McAvoy was talking about ritual sacrifice. The offering in question was him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Sabrina Tavernise
title: In Ukraine, Blasts Before Dawn, Outrage — Then Panic.
description: After Russia attacked, Ukrainians piled into cars, buses and trains in a frantic retreat west toward safety in Poland. “All Ukraine is exploding!”
content: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — The explosions began before dawn. Loud booms of artillery in the distance, shaking a region that knows conflict and death all too well. Then came an eerie silence, pierced by the crowing of roosters, as people blinkingly stepped out of their homes into the morning light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Leonard Kessler, Colorful Children’s Book Author, Dies at 101
description: He crafted tales of everyday life for early readers. His “Mr. Pine’s Purple House,” first published in 1965, later inspired a new publishing company — and Jeff Bezos.
content: Leonard Kessler, the author and illustrator of hundreds of children’s books for early readers that celebrated the ordinary (“I Have Twenty Teeth — Do You?”) and the not-so-ordinary (“Mr. Pine’s Purple House”), died on Feb. 16 at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 101.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Yeezy Gap/Balenciaga Is Here. Is It Worth It?
description: What exactly are we buying, when we buy fashion? A disruptive collaboration provides one answer. There are others.
content: There was disruption, from the start. A major piece of news dropped unexpectedly, like a dare, right at the feet of the fashion establishment as Milan Fashion Week began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Jay Senter
title: 3 Former Officers Are Convicted of Violating George Floyd’s Civil Rights
description: All of them were charged with willfully violating Mr. Floyd’s constitutional rights by not providing medical care. Two were accused of not intervening to stop a fellow officer.
content: ST. PAUL, Minn. — Three former Minneapolis police officers were found guilty on Thursday of federal crimes for failing to intervene as another officer killed George Floyd by pressing his knee on his neck for more than nine minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
title: Japan, hesitant to impose sanctions on Russia in 2014, embraces them now. One reason: China.
description: Japan was previously reluctant to impose sanctions.
content: TOKYO — Japan’s swift move to enact sanctions against Russia on Wednesday might have seemed a foregone conclusion given its close alliance with the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Cyrano’ Review: Who Wrote the Book of Love?
description: Peter Dinklage wields pen and sword in a musical adaptation of the durable French romance.
content: Cyrano de Bergerac is a lover and a fighter, but when we first meet him he is indulging in a brutal bit of theater criticism. Played with grace and gusto by Peter Dinklage, Cyrano emerges from a standing-room-only crowd to berate a pompous actor and drive him from the stage. With cutting rhymes and a sharp sword, he defends dramatic truth against the woeful thespian’s powdered preening. The audience, which had paid to see Cyrano’s victim, nonetheless mostly applauds his humiliation. The few who object are marked as fools, phonies or outright villains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: A New Kind of Model: Giant, Inflatable, Aggressively Sexy
description: Diesel took a novel approach to inclusive casting at its Milan Fashion Week show.
content: There’s a lot to see at fashion week. Blink (or scroll too fast) and you’ll miss the details: feathered bags, futuristic sunglasses, fork jewelry. All month long, we’ll spotlight the things we saw that surprised or delighted us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: 3 Men Plead Guilty in Plot to Attack U.S. Power Grid
description: The men believed that by knocking out power across the country, economic and civil unrest would spread, creating the potential for a race war and the opportunity for white leaders to rise, prosecutors said.
content: Three men pleaded guilty on Wednesday in a plot to attack power grids in the United States, which they believed could lead to economic and civil unrest and create the opportunity for white leaders to rise, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Refugee resettlement leaders urge Biden to welcome Ukrainians to the U.S.
description: The U.S. refugee program is already under pressure to absorb more than 70,000 evacuees from Afghanistan who arrived last year.
content: As international humanitarian groups warned that the Russian invasion could trigger a major exodus from Ukraine, some refugee resettlement leaders in the United States called on the Biden administration to prepare to welcome people fleeing for their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Friends and Strangers’ Review: G’day, Mates
description: In this funny, productively cryptic Australian feature, the characters are alternately abrasive and invasive.
content: The opening credits of “Friends and Strangers,” a funny, productively cryptic debut feature from James Vaughan, unfold over a series of watercolors painted during the first years of Australia’s colonization; they are synced to a score from a silent film, and the first shot after they end seems inspired by the pointillist Georges Seurat. All of this might be taken as an invitation to look beyond dialogue, to pay attention to gaps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: It’s the Highest-Profile Challenge of an Earnest Tenor’s Career
description: Matthew Polenzani, a Met Opera stalwart known more for sweetness than swagger, stars in a new production of Verdi’s “Don Carlos.”
content: Matthew Polenzani wanted to make something clear: He just isn’t a powerhouse tenor like Mario Del Monaco or Franco Corelli, two 20th-century greats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Aleksei Navalny, Putin’s most prominent critic, condemns the invasion.
description: The opposition politician accused the Russian leader of using the attack to divert attention away from the country’s own internal problems.
content: Aleksei A. Navalny, the jailed Russian opposition politician, used a court hearing on Thursday to condemn President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Solomon
title: James Turrell Takes Up Curating, With a Show by His Hero
description: What does Turrell, the master of light, have in common with Ad Reinhardt, the master of dark? Benches, for starters.
content: A compelling new show at the Pace Gallery in Manhattan, “Ad Reinhardt: Color Out of Darkness,” comes with an unusual perk. It has been “curated by James Turrell,” as the subtitle proclaims. The prospect of Turrell, an American master of light, presiding over a show of paintings by Reinhardt, an American master of dark, has a special allure, offering not only two visions for the price of one but a glimpse at the improbable ways of inspiration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: Picturing Black Childhood: An Artist’s Journey
description: Long devoted to the subject of Black girlhood, now the focus of two new exhibitions, Deborah Roberts reflects on what has changed and what hasn’t when it comes to self-representation, play and power.
content: In 2009, sensitive to the ways that Black girls are under particular duress in American culture, the Austin-based artist Deborah Roberts began creating intricate collages of innocence and joy — “very Black Norman Rockwell,” as she described them in a recent interview. When she decided to pursue an M.F.A. in 2014 at age 48, hoping to discover ways to move her work forward, she was struck by how little research there was to draw upon to understand the lives of Black girls and the challenges they faced. “There was scholarship on Black women,” she explained, “but not on how we become Black women.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Juror to Be Questioned as Ghislaine Maxwell Seeks New Trial
description: A federal judge is trying to see whether a juror lied during the selection process, casting doubt on the guilty verdict.
content: A federal judge on Thursday ordered a hearing into whether a juror who served in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial lied during the jury selection process, an issue that has clouded the jury’s guilty verdict and led Ms. Maxwell to seek a new trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: With the Ukraine Invasion, NATO Is Suddenly Vulnerable
description: A Russia in control of Ukraine and Belarus would change the security architecture of Europe. Can the alliance respond effectively?
content: BRUSSELS — A new front line of conflict is taking shape in Europe, with enhanced levels of risk that raise questions about whether NATO will, or even can, respond effectively.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Cases decline in Kentucky, but hospitalizations and the positivity rate remain high.
description: Only 56 percent of state residents are vaccinated, well below the national average. “We would like to see all of those numbers get better,” Gov. Andy Beshear said this week.
content: Kentucky, one of the least vaccinated states in the country, continues to struggle with the coronavirus, with a higher positivity rate and more people hospitalized compared with other parts of the United States, even as its case numbers follow the national trend downward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Bob Beckel, Liberal Operative Who Became a Fixture on Fox, Dies at 73
description: He ran Walter Mondale’s 1984 presidential campaign, and later became a curmudgeonly pundit on conservative TV.
content: Bob Beckel, who parlayed a long career as a Democratic political operative into an even longer one as a TV pundit, mostly for Fox News, where he assumed the role of avuncular in-house liberal with a penchant for saying whatever was on his mind, died on Sunday at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What’s Next in the West’s Response to Russia
description: Western leaders promise severe sanctions as Russian forces attack Ukraine.
content: Early this morning, President Vladimir Putin of Russia ordered what he called a “special military operation” in Ukraine, which looks like an invasion from air, land and sea. Ukraine said it faced a “full-scale attack from multiple directions.” Blasts were heard around the country, and people lined up at banks to withdraw cash and at gas stations to fill up their cars to leave cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Justice Dept. Sues to Block $13 Billion Deal by UnitedHealth Group
description: The agency’s lawsuit against the deal for a health technology company is the latest move by the Biden administration to quash corporate consolidation.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Thursday sued to block a $13 billion acquisition of a health technology company by a subsidiary of UnitedHealth Group, in the latest move by the Biden administration to clamp down on corporate consolidation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Citigroup to Get Rid of Overdraft Fees, the Biggest Bank to Do So
description: The fees have been criticized by regulators. Citi’s move follows similar actions by smaller lenders like Capital One and Ally Financial.
content: Citigroup will eliminate overdraft fees this year, becoming the biggest lender in the nation to get rid of the charges, which regulators have criticized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Laundered Money Could Be Putin’s Achilles’ Heel
description: We can and should freeze oligarchs’ overseas assets.
content: The United States and its allies aren’t going to intervene with their own forces against Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine. I’ll leave it to others with relevant expertise to speculate about whether we’ll send more arms to the Ukrainian government or, if the Russian attack achieves quick success, help arm the Ukrainian resistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Ukraine Invasion Threatens Global Wheat Supply
description: Russia and Ukraine together produce nearly a quarter of the world’s wheat, and coming disruptions could fuel higher food prices and social unrest.
content: The Russian invasion of Ukraine is threatening to cut off some international shipments of wheat, spurring shortages and pushing the price of a vital crop higher when supply chain disruptions have already sent food costs spiraling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Using Science and Celtic Wisdom to Save Trees (and Souls)
description: Diana Beresford-Kroeger, a botanist and author, has created a forest with tree species handpicked for their ability to withstand a warming planet.
content: MERRICKVILLE, Ontario — There aren’t many scientists raised in the ways of druids by Celtic medicine women, but there is at least one. She lives in the woods of Canada, in a forest she helped grow. From there, wielding just a pencil, she has been working to save some of the oldest life-forms on Earth by bewitching its humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Vulnerable Democrats, Seeking Distance From the Left, Offer a Midterm Agenda
description: The plan aims to inoculate Democrats in conservative-leaning states from Republican attacks on cultural issues, underscoring how successful the G.O.P. has been at weaponizing them.
content: WASHINGTON — A cluster of House Democrats from conservative-leaning districts is circulating a reworked legislative agenda for the coming election season that would embrace some of President Biden’s most popular initiatives and tackle rising prices while distancing lawmakers from the left’s most divisive ideas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott and Daniel Arnold
title: Shelf Life: Our Collections and the Passage of Time
description: Set off by a scene in a movie, a critic reflects on cultural baggage: “The things you loved when you were young will never be able to make you young again.”
content: Like a lot of other people, I enjoyed Joachim Trier’s “The Worst Person in the World,” a young woman’s coming-of-age story that’s also a spiky romantic comedy of sorts. But the reason I can’t stop thinking about this movie (which I can’t discuss further without risking spoilers, so be warned) has to do with its status as a Gen X midlife cri de coeur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Big Gold Brick’ Review: Sad Sack Makes Good
description: Shaggy and dull, this film follows a slovenly writer who’s taken in by the man who hit him with a car.
content: Samuel, a nice failed writer and slob, turns his life around one day by stepping in front of a car in “Big Gold Brick.” But success — a best-selling memoir — doesn’t happen overnight. First the wealthy driver, Floyd (Andy Garcia), takes in Samuel (Emory Cohen) as his in-house biographer, and a movie’s worth of mostly domestic misadventures follow that are shaggy and dull.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Kurtz
title: The Battle for the Soul of the Library
description: Librarians should be politically neutral. Too many aren’t.
content: Recent news stories covering clashes over what books students should read in class and have access to in their school libraries have overlooked a major player in our unfolding scholastic drama. We’ve been reading about traditionalist parents, progressive teachers and politicians of various stripes. Missing, however, has been the figure of the woke librarian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Some, but not all, former European leaders quit Russian boards.
description: Ex-heads of government left the boards of some prominent Russian companies after Ukraine was attacked, except the most prominent — Germany’s ex-chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.
content: A former Austrian chancellor and ex-prime ministers of Italy and Finland were among the officials who quit their positions on the boards of leading Russian companies on Thursday in protest over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: A new distribution system is helping African countries ramp up vaccinations.
description: Since January, the countries have been able to request the Covid vaccines they need from the W.H.O. directly, and in what quantity and when.
content: African countries will be able to dramatically accelerate their vaccination programs because the system of distributing Covid vaccines has changed, World Health Organization officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Anton Troianovski, Marc Santora and Shashank Bengali
title: Here’s how the Russian attack is unfolding.
description: As President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on television that he had decided “to carry out a special military operation” in Ukraine, explosions were reported across the country.
content: Early Thursday, just as President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced on television that he had decided “to carry out a special military operation” in Ukraine, explosions were reported across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Kyle Abraham’s Theatrical Love Letter to Social Dance
description: In “An Untitled Love,” an hourlong show at BAM, Abraham and his dancers turn the stage into a house party set to D’Angelo tracks.
content: The couch is the tip off. Ordinary but comfy-looking, covered in plastic, it’s onstage throughout Kyle Abraham’s newest work, “An Untitled Love,” serving the function that couches usually do. Here it signals that this dance is a house party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: How Do You Say ‘Kardashian’ in Italian?
description: The Ferragni sisters already have millions of followers and a reality TV show. Now they’re working on their fashion empires.
content: When Chiara Ferragni joined the board of the Italian luxury brand Tod’s, the company’s stock rose 12 percent. Ms. Ferragni is a 34-year-old mother of two with more than 26 million followers on Instagram, and one of the world’s most famous fashion influencers, particularly in Europe. Her businesses include a clothing brand and a talent agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Katie Robertson
title: Cable News Covers Ukraine With On-the-Ground Reporting and In-Studio Rhetoric
description: Fox News stars like Tucker Carlson questioned why Americans hated Vladimir Putin, and CNN showed Russian tanks and rockets in live war-zone dispatches.
content: The 24-hour television news cycle took on a new kind of challenge on Thursday: a ground war unfolding in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Renard
title: What’s in Our Queue? Australian Post-Punks and More
description: I’m an editor on the Times Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
content: I’m an editor on the Times Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar
title: What to Know: India’s Local Elections
description: Five states in India, with nearly 300 million people, are voting in local elections this month that will also give a broader sense of India’s political direction and mood.
content: Five states in India, with nearly 300 million people, are voting in local elections this month that will also give a broader sense of India’s political direction and mood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Chen
title: How to Conquer Noises So You Can Sleep
description: As long as you counteract the noise, you won't actually need absolute silence.
